or accessing the content or web pages uh so when you need to do that uh you need
to have a CDN that is basically going to be a network of servers scattered all around the world that cach the content
that basically take the content from where it's stored on An Origin server and bring it out to servers that are
closer to where your end users are uh so that content can be delivered to them uh
more quickly so for instance when a specific web page or maybe if you're delivering a

low latency uh anywhere in the world that can happen through a number
of different ways so you can look at physical proximity to the end users and you know potentially deliver from a

delivered from uh content is then in in a CDN is
replicated to all the servers uh that are around the world so uh you may have heard at the keynote earlier today we

cache the content from your Edge or from your origin server uh so that it's replicated across all of the different

you know do you end up with uh sort of that buffering that you see a lot of times you really don't want that end

results oops uh reducing the uh the load on the origin or the web server so
traditionally what you have is all your your content whether it's webpage content or videos if you're delivering
videos would be stored on An Origin server origin server is you know basically the term for where you're
storing all that uh the content that you're delivering if you have a huge
number of users trying to access that one origin server that small handful of origin servers uh all at the same time
like let's say some you know your your web page or some image or a video becomes very popular goes viral on the
internet if everybody tried to access that content all at the same time that server
might tip over and you know just they'd get a denial of service basically because they wouldn't get the content

Edge locations instead of just that one origin
uh having a CDN in place can make your site more reliable so again if if for instance uh everybody's trying to access
the server all at the same time if it falls over that's not very reliable if
all that content is replicated all over the world to thousands of servers if one of those servers goes down nobody ever
notices it because the content can be delivered from the next server uh providing protection again
redundancy across many many servers can protect protect you from potentially
denial of service attacks if you've got bad guys out there that are trying to bring down your website uh they're going to have a much harder time trying to
bring it down if it if the content is replicated across many servers around the
world and then again mobile users that maybe have limited bandwidth connections uh using a Content delivery Network can

is the data transfer so how much data are you transferring out to end users
from The Edge locations so that's one component the other component is request fees so how many requests for Content
are coming in depending on the type of content that you're delivering those costs can be a a larger or smaller
percentage of the overall cost so as an example if you're delivering video
um the objects that you're delivering are going to be quite a bit bigger so you're going to have more data transfer
uh component to your cost versus the request fees if you're delivering something like uh you know a piece of
website Chrome that's on the homepage that's very small file uh that might get a lot of requests but it's a very small
amount of of uh data transfer so the cost would potentially you know the component of the transfer cost would be

we call resered capacity pricing now in general a lot of people use our tiered
pricing which is kind of what we call our public pricing what's available up on the website again the more you use
the the less expensive it gets our Reserve capacity pricing model is
basically for customers that are using um significant amounts of cloudfront delivery on a sustained basis each month
